HOP.NAME: Admiral
HOP.NOTES: Bittering hops derived from Wye Challenger. Good high-alpha bittering hops. Used for: Ales Aroma: Primarily for bittering Substitutes: Target, Northdown, Challenger

HOP.NAME: Agnus
HOP.NOTES: Several large Czech breweries like Agnus as a bittering hop because its alpha/beta ratio is relatively high, which they believe makes their beer more stable. High geraniol level, oils indicate dry hopping potential. Used for: Ales Aroma: Strong hop aroma, spicy Substitutions: Unknown Storage: Unknown 9-15% AA / 4-8% Beta

HOP.NAME: Ahtanum
HOP.NOTES: Distinctive aromatic hops with moderate bittering power from Washington. Used for: American ales and lagers Aroma: Distinctive floral and citrus aromas Substitutes: Amarillo, Cascade

HOP.NAME: Amarillo
HOP.NOTES: Discovered and introduced by Vigil Gamache Farms Inc. in Washington State. Character similar to Cascade. Often used as a late kettle or dry hop addition to American style Pale Ales and IPA’s due to its signature aroma characteristics. Used for both bitterness and aroma. Used for: IPAs, Ales Aroma: Intensely fruity (citrus, melon, and stone friuts), floral, tropical notes. Substitutes: Cascade, Centennial, Simcoe Storage: Good 8-11% AA / 6-7% Beta

HOP.NAME: Amarillo Gold
HOP.NOTES: Unknown origin, but character similar to Cascade. Used for both bitterness and aroma. Used for: IPAs, Ales Aroma: Citrus, flowery Substitutes: Cascade, Centennial

HOP.NAME: Apollo
HOP.NOTES: Super high alpha variety from the Hopsteiner breeding program released in 2006. High alpha and low cohumulone makes it a great bittering hop. Adds a strong grapefruit/hop note if added late in boil. Used for: IPA, IIPA Aroma: Strong grapefruit and hoppy notes Substitutes: Nugget, CTZ, Bravo Storage: Excellent/Very Good (80-90% AA remaining after 6 months at 20 C) 15-19% AA / 5.5-8% Beta

HOP.NAME: Aquila
HOP.NOTES: Aroma hops developed in 1988. Limited use due to high cohumolone. Used for: Aroma hops Substitutes: Cluster No longer commercially grown.

HOP.NAME: Atlas
HOP.NOTES: A cross between Brewers Gold and Slovenian wild hops. Primarily a bittering hop with pleasant bitterness and aroma. Used for: Bittering ales, lagers Substitutes: Brewers Gold

HOP.NAME: Atlas (Styrian Atlas)
HOP.NOTES: A cross between Brewers Gold and Slovenian wild hops. Primarily a bittering hop with pleasant bitterness and aroma. Used for: Bittering ales, lagers Aroma: Fresh hoppy aroma Substitutes: Brewers Gold Storage: Very Good 7-11% AA / 3.2-41% Beta

HOP.NAME: Aurora
HOP.NOTES: Also called Super Styrian. This is a hybrid between Northern Brewer and TG. It has a pleasant hoppy aroma similar to Styrian Goldings but lighter. Used for: Often mixed with other hops in lagers. Substitutes: Styrian Goldings

HOP.NAME: Aurora (Super Styrian Aurora)
HOP.NOTES: Also called Super Styrian Aurora. This is a hybrid between Northern Brewer and TG. Pleasant hoppy aroma similar to Styrian Golding but lighter. Used for: Strong Ale, Pale Ale, Bitter Aroma: Intense and pleasant hoppy aroma Substitutes: Styrian Golding Storage: Excellent/Very Good (80-85% AA after 6 months at 20 C) 7-9% AA/ 3-5% Beta

HOP.NAME: Banner
HOP.NOTES: Bittering hops developed in 1988. Use largely discontinued due to poor storage. Used for: U.S. style ales Substitutes: Cluster

HOP.NAME: Belma
HOP.NOTES: New variety produced at Puterbaugh Farms. First introduced to public Fall 2012. Used for: Expedrimental Ales and Lagers Aroma: A very clean hop, with a very orange, slight grapefruit, tropical (but not mango/guava, more like pineapple), strawberry, and melon Substitutions: Unknown Storage: Unknown 9.8% AA / ??% Beta (5 year avg not yet established)

HOP.NAME: Boadicea
HOP.NOTES: Released in 2004. Excellent for finishing and dry hopping. Used for: Ales Aroma: Mild floral and spicy characteristics with slightly grassy overtones Substitutions: Unknown Storage: Unknown 7-10% AA / 3-4% Beta

HOP.NAME: Bobek
HOP.NOTES: Also called Styrian Golding B - a cross between Northern Brewer and a TG seedling. Pleasant hop aroma and flavor. Used for: Moderate English ales and lagers/Pilsners Substitutes: Northern Brewer

HOP.NAME: Bobek (Styrian Golding B)
HOP.NOTES: Also called Styrian Golding B - a cross between Northern Brewer and a TG seedling. Used for: English Ales, ESB, Lagers, Pilsners Aroma: Intense and pleasant hoppy aroma Substitutes: Northern Brewer, Styrian Golding, UK or US Fuggle, Willamette Storage: Unknown 3.5-7% AA / 4-6.1% Beta

HOP.NAME: Bramling Cross
HOP.NOTES: Developed in 1927 from commercial Goldings and wild hop variety. Used for: ESB, Bitters, Pale Ale Aroma: Mild, fruity, currant aroma. Substitutes: East Kent Goldings, Progress, Whitbred

HOP.NAME: Bravo
HOP.NOTES: A second generation super high alpha hops from the Hopsteiner breeding program released in 2006. Good bittering hop. Aroma: Fruity and floral aroma. Substitutes: Columbus, Zeus, Tomahawk

HOP.NAME: Brewer's Gold
HOP.NOTES: Primarily a bittering hop and commonly used in lighter style ales, although it works well in lagers. Used for: English ales, German styles, farmhouse ales. Aroma: Bittering hop with neutral aroma character, spice noted to its flavor and aroma Substitutes: Northdown, Northern Brewer (Germany), Galena, Bullion, Chinnok, Cascade (U.S.) Storage: Fair (60-70% AA after 6 months at 20 C) 7-10% AA / 3.5-4.5% Beta

HOP.NAME: Bullion
HOP.NOTES: A major hop variety since the mid-1940s, however, product ceased in 1985 due to super alpha hops with better storage stability. Commonly used in darker beers. Used for: Stouts, ESB, Scotch Ale, IPA, Porter, Heavy German lagers. Aroma: Strong, pungent and bitter in flavor. Intense Black currant aroma. Substitutes: Chinook, Galena, Eroica, Columbus, Northern Brewer (German), Brewer's Gold (German). Storage: Poor (40%-50% AA after 6 months at 20 C) 6.5-9% AA / 3.2-6% Beta

HOP.NAME: Bullion
HOP.NOTES: Used in strong dark English ales, some heavy German lagers. Aroma: Strong, pungent and bitter in flavor. Blackcurrant flavor. Substitutes: Chinook, Eroica, Brewer's Gold

HOP.NAME: Calypso
HOP.NOTES: A new, dual-purpose hop from the Hopsteiner breeding program that may establish itself as "special". Used for: Ales, Stouts and Barley Wines Aroma: Not as tropical as the name might imply but rich in both stone fruits (pear and peaches, notes of cherry) and citrus. Substitutions: Unknown Storage: Good (65-70% AA after 6 months at 20 C) 12-14% AA / 5-6% Beta

HOP.NAME: Cascade
HOP.NOTES: A hops with Northern Brewers Heritage Used for: American ales and lagers Aroma: Strong spicy, floral, grapefruit character Substitutes: Centennial Examples: Sierra Nevada Pale Ale, Anchor Liberty Ale

HOP.NAME: Celeia
HOP.NOTES: A dual purpose hops that is a hybrid between Savinjski Golding, Aurora and Slovenian wild hops. Similar in aroma to Saaz. Used for: Light lagers, Pilsners, Belgian ales. Substitutes: Saaz, Styrian Goldings

HOP.NAME: Centennial
HOP.NOTES: Used for: General purpose bittering, aroma in American ales and Wheats Aroma: Floral, citrus aroma, spicy, clean bittering flavor Substitutes: Galena, Eroica, Nugget, Bullion Examples: Sierra Nevada Celebration Ale, Sierra Nevada Bigfoot

HOP.NAME: Challenger
HOP.NOTES: Variant of Northern Brewers heritage Used for: Both aroma and bittering for ales and lagers Aroma: Fruity in flavor, spicy aroma, blends well Substitutes: N/A

HOP.NAME: Chelan
HOP.NOTES: High alpha variety from the Haas breeding program released in 2004. It is a variant of Galena and very similar in profile to Galena. Aroma: Pleasant citrus notes Substitutes: Galena

HOP.NAME: Chinook
HOP.NOTES: Strong versatile bittering hop Used for: Ales, porters, stouts Aroma: Heavy and spicy aroma Substitutes: Galena, Eroica, Nugget, Bullion Examples: Sierra Nevada Stout, Sierra Nevada Celebration Ale

HOP.NAME: Citra
HOP.NOTES: Special aroma hops released in 2007. Imparts high alpha/oil content but low cohumulone. Aroma: Adds interesting citrus and tropical fruit character to the beer. Substitutes: Unknown

HOP.NAME: Cluster
HOP.NOTES: Used for: General purpose bittering hop Aroma: Floral, slightly spicy. Sharp aroma and sharp flavor Substitutes: Eroica, Galena

HOP.NAME: Columbia
HOP.NOTES: Sibling of Williamette hops. Used for: All English Ales Aroma: Close to Fuggles Substitutes: Fuggles, Williamette

HOP.NAME: Columbus (Tomahawk)
HOP.NOTES: Engineered Centennial Substitute - High alpha bittering hops. Used for: Bittering, flavor, aroma - IPA, American Pale Ale, Stout, Lager Aroma: Pungent, spicy. Strongly aromatic, but clean tasting bitterness Substitutes: Centennial

HOP.NAME: Columbus/Tomahawk/Zeus (CTZ)
HOP.NOTES: Engineered Centennial Substitute - High alpha bittering hops. Used for: IPA, American Pale Ale, Stout, Lager, Barley Wine Aroma: Pungent, spicy. Strongly aromatic, but clean tasting bitterness Substitutes: Other CTZ, Galena, Chinook, Nugget, Target (U.K.), Northern Brewer (Germany) Storage: Poor/Very Poor (45-65% AA after 6 months at 20 C) 14-16.5% AA / 4-5% Beta

HOP.NAME: Comet
HOP.NOTES: Very bitter hops - use sparingly with other hops Used for: Bittering only Substitutes: N/A

HOP.NAME: Crystal
HOP.NOTES: Used for: Aroma and finishing hops for Lagers Aroma: Clean, mild, pleasant and slightly spicy Substitutes: Hallertauer, Mount Liberty

HOP.NAME: Delta
HOP.NOTES: A backcross between Fuggles and Cascade, recently released (2012) by the Hopsteiner breeding program. Woody and herbal with a citrus kick. Not as assertive as dual purpose hops but adds distinctive notes in a blend. Used for: IPA, Pale Ale Aroma: Mild and pleasant aroma; slightly spicy with a hint of citrus. Substitutions: Fuggle, Willamette Storage: Excellent (80-90% AA after 6 months at 20 C) 5-7% AA / 5-7% Beta

HOP.NAME: East Kent Goldings (EKG)
HOP.NOTES: Also known as Canterbury Hops by some, although others will dispute this fact. East Kent Goldings gracefully defines the English Pale Ales and Ales produced by the region, it is quintessentially English. Used for: English Ale, Porter, Scottish and Irish Ale, Stout, Strong Ale, ESB, Saison, Barleywine. Aroma: Floral, aromatic, earthy, slightly sweet spicy flavor Substitutes: First Gold, Fuggles, other Golding varieties, Progress, Target, and Whitbread Golding Storage: Good/Fair 965-80% AA after 6 months at 20 C) 4-7% AA / 1.9-2.8% Beta

HOP.NAME: El Dorado
HOP.NOTES: Bred by CLS Farms, LLC, available on a larger scale for the first time during 2012 harvest. Fits the dual purpose/special mold. Used for: Experimental Ales Aroma: Tropical fruit flavors, intense aromas of stone fruits (pear, cherries), candy (Lifesavers), watermelon. Substitutions: None at this time Storage: Good 14-16% AA / 7-8% Beta

HOP.NAME: Ella (aka Stella)
HOP.NOTES: New name after a 2013 harvest in Australia (due to name infringement). Despite high alpha, sold as an aroma variety. When used in dry hopping or higher quantities, grapefruit and tropical characters come to the fore. Character obtained at lower rates can be best appreciated in lagers or pilsners, while the grapefruit and tropical flavors can be used to offset robust malt and yeast characters Used for: Ales, Lagers, Pilsners Aroma: tropical, subtle hints of star anise, sweet and floral, with lemon, grapefruit, apricot, and melon. Substitutions: Galaxy Storage: Unknown 13.3-16.3% AA / 4-7.8% Beta

HOP.NAME: Eroica
HOP.NOTES: Used for: General purpose bittering for ales, porters, stouts Aroma: Clean bittering hop, very bitter Substitutes: Galena, Northern Brewer, Chinook Examples: Blackhook Porter, Ballard Bitter

HOP.NAME: Falconer's Flight
HOP.NOTES: Proprietary pellet blend comprised of many of the Northwest’s most unique hop varieties and is perfect for any Northwest-style IPA. Used for: IPA, Pale Ale, Experimental Ale Aroma: distinct tropical, citrus, floral, lemon and grapefruit tones. Substitutions: Unknown (Citra, Simcoe, Sorachi Ace blend?) Storage: Unknown 10-12% AA / 4.4% Beta

HOP.NAME: Falconer's Flight 7C's Blend
HOP.NOTES: A proprietary hop blend from HopUnion that includes 7 of the "C" hops along with a few experimental varieties. Used for: Pale Ale, IPA, Experimental Ales Aroma: Citrus/grapefruit character alongside fruity, spicy, and earthy notes Substitutions: Unknown Storage: Unknown 9-10% AA / 4.5% Beta

HOP.NAME: Feux Coeur Francais
HOP.NOTES: Rare, high alpha hops from Australia with genetic roots in the Burgundy region of France. It was adopted to the Victoria region of Australia and introduced in 2010.

HOP.NAME: First Gold
HOP.NOTES: Dwarf hop with English Golding character Used for: Ales, ESB Aroma: Similar to other Golding varieties, spicy Substitutes: East Kent Goldings, Crystal

HOP.NAME: Fuggle
HOP.NOTES: Traditional English-type aroma hop. Used for: English Ales, ESB, Bitter, Lagers Aroma: Mild, soft, fruity, spicy, woody Substitute: Fuggle (U.S.), Willamette, Styrian Golding Storage: Good/Very Good (70-80% AA after 6 months at 20 C) 3-5.6% AA 2-3% Beta

HOP.NAME: Fuggle, Organic
HOP.NOTES: As Fuggle (U.K.), only organic variety Typical alpha: 3-5%. Organically grown Fuggle hops from the UK. Wonderful earthy, pipe-tobacco, floral character. Classic hop for any English ale.

HOP.NAME: Fuggles
HOP.NOTES: Used for: General purpose bittering/aroma for English Ales, Dark Lagers Aroma: Mild, soft, grassy, floral aroma Substitute: East Kent Goldings, Williamette Examples: Samuel Smith's Pale Ale, Old Peculiar, Thomas Hardy's Ale

HOP.NAME: Galaxy
HOP.NOTES: A high alpha, dual purpose seedless hops with a unique hop aroma. It can be used either for bittering or as a late hop addition to provide a flavor of citrus and passionfruit to the finished beer. Aroma: Intense, pleasant, unique.

HOP.NAME: Galena
HOP.NOTES: Used for: General bittering hops for all beers Aroma: Strong, clean, balanced bittering Substitutes: Eroica, Northern Brewer, Cluster, Chinook Examples: Catamount Porter

HOP.NAME: German Tradition
HOP.NOTES: Close descendant of Hallertauer Mittelfrueh bred for high yield. Used for: Lager, Pilsner, Bock, some Weizens Aroma: Medium intense floral and herbal (grassy) tones Substitutes: Hallertau Mittelfruh, Liberty, Hersbrucker Storage: Unknown 5-7% AA / 4-5% Beta

HOP.NAME: Glacier
HOP.NOTES: Genetic mix of at least 8 hops including Elsasser, Brewers Gold, N Brewer, Bullion, Early Green, and others...released in 2000. Used for: Aroma Aroma: Excellent, hoppy Substitutes: N/A

HOP.NAME: Goldings, B.C.
HOP.NOTES: Used for: Bittering and finishing British ales, bitters, porters and stouts. Aroma: Spicy, floral, rounded mild aroma. Substitutes: East Kent Goldings, Fuggles

HOP.NAME: Goldings, East Kent
HOP.NOTES: Used for: General purpose hops for bittering/finishing all British Ales Aroma: Floral, aromatic, earthy, slightly sweet spicy flavor Substitutes: Fuggles, BC Goldings Examples: Bass Pale Ale, Fullers ESB, Samual Smith's Pale Ale

HOP.NAME: Green Bullet
HOP.NOTES: Bittering hops from New Zealand developed in 1972 Used for: Australian-style ales and lagers. Aroma: Floral, raisin aroma. Substitutes: Styrian Goldings

HOP.NAME: Greenburg
HOP.NOTES: American hop variety from southern Idaho. Fruity flavor with a touch of wood flavor. Popular with microbreweries.

HOP.NAME: HBC 291 (Experimental)
HOP.NOTES: As this is an experimental variety, there is no guarantee this hop will come to market en masse. Data obtained from HopUnion Uses: Unknown Aroma: Typically described as peppery, floral and fruity Substitutions: Unknown Storage: Unknown 11.2-13.1% AA / 5.1-6.1% Beta

HOP.NAME: HBC 342 (Experimental)
HOP.NOTES: As this is an experimental variety, there is no guarantee this hop will come to market en masse. Data obtained from HopUnion. "High alpha variety with a pleasant aroma" Uses: Pale Ale Aroma: Mild citrus, tropical fruit and melon notes Substitutions: Unknown (Belma or Citra?) Storage: Unknown ??% AA / ??% Beta

HOP.NAME: HBC 366 (Experimental)
HOP.NOTES: As this is an experimental variety, there is no guarantee this hop will come to market en masse. Data obtained from HopUnion. "The fantastic aroma combined with the high high oils make this hop very unique" Uses: Experimental Ale Aroma: Exceptional aroma profile includes notes of citrus, tropical and pine Substitutions: Unknown Storage: Unknown 14.4-15.6% AA / 4.6-5.1% Beta

HOP.NAME: Hallertau
HOP.NOTES: This traditional German land-race variety has limited acreage in the U.S. Used for: lager, pilsner, bock, wheat, Munich Helles, or Belgian style. Aroma: considered mild, pleasant, and slightly flowery & spicy. Substitutions: Liberty, German Hallertau, German Tradition Storage: Fair (50-60% AA after 6 months at 20 C) 3.5-5.5% AA / 3.5-5.5% Beta

HOP.NAME: Hallertau Magnum
HOP.NOTES: German Hallertauer hybrid, widely used in Germany. Extremely appropriate for early boil additions. Used for: German ales and lagers, bitters, IPAs, pilsners, pale ales, stouts. Aroma: somewhat unnoticeable aroma; stable spicy flavor Substitutes: Hallertau Taurus, Columbus, Nugget Storage: Excellent (80%-85% AA after 6 months at 20 C) 12-14% AA / 4.5-5.5% Beta

HOP.NAME: Hallertau Taurus
HOP.NOTES: Bred at the Huell Hops Institute in Germany and prided in its bittering qualities. The bittering is moderately abundant and this variety adds a pleasant aroma as well. Used for: Schwawrz, Oktoberfest, Lager Aroma: seasoned, flavorful, zesty character Substitutions: Hallertau Magnum, German Tradition Storage: Fair/Good (60%-70% AA after 6 months at 20 C) 12.3-17.9% AA / 4-6% Beta

HOP.NAME: Hallertauer
HOP.NOTES: Used for: German Ales, German/US/Canadian Lagers, Wheat Beers Aroma: Pleasant, mild spicy flavor, clean, neutral flavor Substitutes: Crystal, Liberty, Hallertauer Mittelfrueh

HOP.NAME: Hallertauer Hersbrucker
HOP.NOTES: Used for: German style lagers and wheat beers Aroma: Noble, pleasant, clean flavor Substitutes: Mt. Hood, Liberty, Hallertauer, Mittelfrueh Examples: Wheathook Wheaten Ale

HOP.NAME: Hallertauer Mittelfrueh
HOP.NOTES: Used for: Continental Lagers, German Ales/Lagers, US Lagers Aroma: Pleasant, assertive, mild herbal aroma Substitutes: Hallertauer, Mt. Hood, Liberty, Crystal Examples: Sam Adams Boston Lager, Sam Adams Boston Lightship

HOP.NAME: Hallertauer, New Zealand
HOP.NOTES: Hallertauer variant with classic aroma and ability to retain clean taste. Bred from German Hallertauer Mittelfrueh Used for: Australian Ales Substitutes: Hallertauer Mittelfrueh

HOP.NAME: Harmonie
HOP.NOTES: With typical Czech aroma, Harmonie's finely balanced bitterness "persists" slightly longer than Saaz. Bohemie, released in 2010, is a similar Czech hop with traditional aroma. 5-8% AA / 5-8% Beta

HOP.NAME: Helga (Southern Hallertau)
HOP.NOTES: Perviously known as Southern Hallertau. Bears almost no aroma similarities to it's European cousin. Very unique aroma with moderate bittering. Used for: Austrialian and English-style ales. Aroma: Ddelicate floral and subtle herbal aroma Substitutes: Unknown (possible Nobel Hop variety) Storage: Unknown 5-6% AA / 3.8-5.4% Beta

HOP.NAME: Herald
HOP.NOTES: Dwarf variety bred at Wye College (mid 1990s) Used for: Bittering of ales Aroma: Strong, acceptable Substitutes: High alpha English bittering hops

HOP.NAME: Herkules
HOP.NOTES: A German high alpha cross variety, bred in Huell and released in 2005. Imparts robust, hoppy tang flavors. Used for: hoppy German-style ales or lagers Aroma: Spicy floral and hop notes, with hints of pine, lemon and black pepper. Substitutions: Unknown Storage: Good 13-17% AA / 4-5.5% Beta

HOP.NAME: Hersbrucker
HOP.NOTES: Hersbrucker Hops is similar to the noble hop varieties with its low co-humulone level. Aroma: Classicly spicy, herbal, with hints of citrus and stone fruit. Used for: German and Bavarian style Lagers, Pilsners, Hefeweizens, Dunkles, and Bocks Substitutions: Mt. Hood, Strisselspalt, Hallertau Mittelfruh, Liberty Storage: Fair (55%-65% AA after 6 months at 20 C) 2-5% AA / 4-6% Beta

HOP.NAME: HopShot
HOP.NOTES: CO2-extracted hop resin that can be used for bittering or late additions to boiling wort. One milliliter of HopShot yields approximately 10 IBUs in 5 gallons of 1.050 wort when boiled for 60 minutes. http://www.northernbrewer.com/documentation/hopshot.pdf

HOP.NAME: Horizon
HOP.NOTES: Good dual purpose hops derived from Nugget hops in Oregon (1970) Used for: All purpose Ales, Lagers Aroma: Pleasant, hoppy Substitutes: Magnum or other high alpha hops

HOP.NAME: Liberty
HOP.NOTES: Used for: German style lagers Aroma: Fine, mild, slightly spicy flavor Substitutes: Hallertau, Mt Hood, Crystal Examples: Pete's Wicked Lager

HOP.NAME: Lublin
HOP.NOTES: Version of Saaz grown in Poland - also called "Lubelski" Used for: Bohemian lagers and Pilsners Aroma: Noble, mild flavor similar to Saaz Substitutes: Saaz, Tettnanger

HOP.NAME: Lublin (Lubelski)
HOP.NOTES: Lublin, also called "Lubelski", was bred from Saaz and carries with it many of the same characteristics. Used for: Bohemian lagers and Pilsners Aroma: Noble, mild flavor similar to Saaz Substitutes: Saaz, Tettnanger, Sterling Storage: Good (70%-75% AA after 6 months at 20 C) 3-5% AA / 2.5-4% Beta

HOP.NAME: Magnum
HOP.NOTES: High-alpha hop with clean, neutral bitterness. Can be used in almost any recipe. Used for: Ale, Lager, Stout, hefeweizen, IPA, Bitter Aroma: No distinctive aroma characteristics Substitutions: German Magnum, CTZ, Nugget Storage: Excellent/Very good (80%-85% AA after 6 months at 20 C) 10-14% AA / 4.5-7% Beta

HOP.NAME: Mandarina Bavaria
HOP.NOTES: One of four new varieties released to German growers in 2012. Shares characteristics of its mother, Cascade, but fruitier and more herbal. Used for: American pale ale, lager (as late hop) Aroma: Distinct tangerine and citrus flavors Substitutions: Unknown Storage: Unknown 7-10% AA / 4-7% Beta

HOP.NAME: Marynka
HOP.NOTES: Bittering hops with high aroma. Primarily for use in Pilsner, lagers, ales or wheats. Comparable to English Goldings or Chinook. Used for: Lager, ales Substitutes: Chinook, English Golding

HOP.NAME: Merkur (Hallertauer Merkur)
HOP.NOTES: Sometimes called Hallertauer Merkur, this variety was bred from a cross between Hallertaur Magnum and variety 81/8/13 from the Hull Hops Research Institute. Mostly used for bittering qualities, appropriate for early to mid additions. Aroma: Strong earthy, floral and citrus impressions Substitutions: Maganum (U.S.), Hallertau Magnum Storage: Fair/Good (60%-70% AA after 6 months at 20 C) 12-16.2% AA / 5.1% Beta

HOP.NAME: Millenium
HOP.NOTES: Originally developed as part of the Haas breeding program in the US, Millenium entered production in 2000. It is a very high alpha hops used for bittering. Aroma: Mild, herbal Substitutes: Columbus, Tomahawk, Zeus and Nugget

HOP.NAME: Mosaic (HBC 369)
HOP.NOTES: Available in quantity for the first time after 2012 harvest. Still known to many as HBC 369. A daughter of Simcoe crossed with a Nugget derived male. An excellent aroma variety. Used for: Ales, IPA, Experimental Ales Aroma: Rich in mango, lemon, citrus, pine, and notably, blueberry. Substitutes: Unknown Storage: Good (25% AA after 6 months at 20 C) 11-13.5% AA / 3.2-3.9% Beta

HOP.NAME: Motueka
HOP.NOTES: Flexible hop developed from Saaz. Has notable character and aroma, balanced bitterness, and unique flavor. Used for: Lagers, Belgian Ales and Bohemian Pilsner. Substitutes: Saaz

HOP.NAME: Mt. Hood
HOP.NOTES: Used for: European Lagers, finishing Aroma: Mild with a clean aroma, neutral flavor. Somewhat pungent. Substitutes: Hallertauer, Liberty, Crystal

HOP.NAME: Mt. Rainier
HOP.NOTES: Complex parentage, including Hallertau, Galena, and Fuggle. HopUnion has stated this hop was only bred thru 2010. Used for: Lager Aroma: Excellent floral and noble aromas, with citrus and licorice tones. Substitutions: Hallertau, Fuggle Storage: Unknown 5-8.1% AA / 5-7% Beta

HOP.NAME: Nelson Sauvin
HOP.NOTES: Triploid variety bred from "Smoothcone" released in 2000. Oil profile said to taste like "fresh crushed gooseberries" similar to Sauvignon Blanc, giving it its name. Very fruity, citrusy - use in moderation. Used for: Pale ale, Super Premiums. Substitutes: None

HOP.NAME: Newport
HOP.NOTES: High alpha hops released in 2002 as a potential replacement for Galena. Note that these hops have a large alpha range of 9.8%-17% so check the package! Fairly pungent. Used for: Primarily used for bittering in ales, stouts, barley wine. Substitutes: Galena

HOP.NAME: Northdown
HOP.NOTES: Variation of Northern Brewers hops grown in England. Used for: Bittering in English ales Aroma: Good bittering, flavor and aroma Substitutes: Northern Brewer

HOP.NAME: Northern Brewer
HOP.NOTES: Also called Hallertauer Northern Brewers Used for: Bittering and finishing both ales and lagers of all kinds Aroma: Fine, dry, clean bittering hop. Unique flavor. Substitutes: Hallertauer Mittelfrueh, Hallertauer Examples: Anchor Steam, Old Peculiar,

HOP.NAME: Nugget
HOP.NOTES: Used for: Bittering hops for ales Aroma: Strong bittering, heavy, herbal aroma, spicy Substitutes: Chinook Examples: Sierra Nevada Porter

HOP.NAME: Olympic
HOP.NOTES: Olympic is a high alpha hops released by Washington Agricultural Expt Station in 1983. Heritage is from Brewers Gold and Fuggles. Aroma: Spicy, citrus aroma Substitutes: Brewers Gold

HOP.NAME: Opal
HOP.NOTES: New variety from the hop research center in Hull. Used for: Aroma hops in continental styles Aroma: High aroma hops with hints of spice and subtle citrus. Substitutes: Unknown

HOP.NAME: Orion
HOP.NOTES: Cross between Perle and an experimental variety Used for: Bittering and aroma Aroma: Pleasant, hoppy Substitutes: Perle

HOP.NAME: Pacific Gem
HOP.NOTES: High alpha smoothcone cross developed at DSIR in 1987. Used for: Bittering - produces a cask-oak woody flavor. Aroma: Pleasant - some blackberry aroma. Substitutes: Bullion

HOP.NAME: Pacific Hallertau (aka Pacifica)
HOP.NOTES: Hallertau variant which produces a typical Mittelfruh aroma combined with smooth bouquet and mild buttery flavor notes; typical of the flavor achieved in classic European lagers Used for: Australian Ales, European lager Aroma: Clean, floral with slight cinnamon-like spiciness. Orange marmalade and citrus aroma notes when used in late addition. Soft finish if used in bittering. Substitutes: Chinook, Hallertauer Mittelfruh, Liberty, Mt. Hood Storage: Good/Very Good 5-6% AA / 5.5-6.2% Beta

HOP.NAME: Pacific Jade
HOP.NOTES: High alpha bittering hops that delivers a bold herbal infusion of fresh citrus with some black pepper flavor. Citrus aroma and flavor tempers ales and may be used as a finishing hops. Used for: Ales, lagers Substitutes: N/A

HOP.NAME: Pacifica
HOP.NOTES: Aroma hop developed from Hallertauer Mittelfrueh in New Zealand (1994). Blend of old and new world taste including Orange marmalade and citrus aroma notes when used in late addition. Soft finish if used in bittering. Substitutes: Chinook, Hallertauer Mittelfrueh

HOP.NAME: Palisade
HOP.NOTES: Also called YCR-4, Palisade is an aroma variety bread by Yakima Chief Ranches. It has both aromatic and moderate bittering properties. Substitutes: Willamette

HOP.NAME: Perle
HOP.NOTES: Perle has a spciy character, and the aroma is moderate and pleasing. Commonly compared to Hallertau Mittlefruh. Used for: German ales, lagers, Plisner, Alt, Maisbier, Dunkle, Kolsch Aroma: Delicate floral and fruity tones Substitutes: Northern Brewer, Perle (U.S.), Hallertau Mittelfruh, Hallertau Aroma Storage: Good 6-10% AA / 2.5-5% Beta

HOP.NAME: Phoenix
HOP.NOTES: Seedling derived from Wye Yoeman. Used for: Ales Aroma: Similar to Wye Challenger hops Substitutes: Challenger, East Kent Golding, Northdown

HOP.NAME: Pilgrim
HOP.NOTES: New variety from Wye College in 2001. High Selinene content. Used for: Bittering Substitutes: N/A

HOP.NAME: Pilot
HOP.NOTES: A very new hops introduced in 2002 by Charles Faram & Co Ltd. Mild herbal flavor with lemon hints and fresh mowed grass flavor. Used for: Primarily for bittering in APAs. Rare.

HOP.NAME: Pioneer
HOP.NOTES: Bred from Wye Omega at Wye College in the UK Used for: ESB, English Ales Aroma: Mild English hop aroma Substitutes: East Kent Goldings

HOP.NAME: Polaris
HOP.NOTES: Very high alpha and stunninly high oil content. Its aroma variously described as "ice candy", eucalyptus, peppermint, and citrus. A variety with bold taste and differentiating flavor. Used for: Lagers, Ales, Pale Ales, IPA Aroma: Intense floral and pleasant mint tones Substitutes: Unknown Storage: Unknown 19-23% AA / 5-7% Beta

HOP.NAME: Premiant
HOP.NOTES: A cross between Czech aroma and bittering varieties. Dual purpose though its aroma is not as strong as some other Czech hops. Use in beers where a moderate hoppy aroma is needed. Used for: Moderate ales, lagers Substitutes: Saaz

HOP.NAME: Pride of Ringwood
HOP.NOTES: Used for: General purpose bittering hops for Australian beers Aroma: Moderate citric aroma, clean bittering flavor Substitutes: Cluster, Galena

HOP.NAME: Progress
HOP.NOTES: Used for: Bittering and aroma in English Ales Aroma: Similar to Fuggles, aromatic, slightly sweet Substitutes: Fuggles

HOP.NAME: Rakau (Alpharoma)
HOP.NOTES: Previously known as Alpharoma. Suited for new world styles where brash fruit character and big but well constructed bitterness is desired. Has been compared to Nelson Sauvin as a "flavor hop". Used for: Pale Ale, IPA, Lager Aroma: Tropical fruit, passion fruit, apricot/peach Substitutions: Amarillo, Summit Storage: Good 10-11% AA / 4.6-6% Beta

HOP.NAME: Riwaka
HOP.NOTES: Formerly called B-Saaz, this was developed from old line Saazer hops in New Zealand. Used for: New world pale ale, regional pilsners Aroma: Strong, hoppy. Some grapefruit and citrus character.

HOP.NAME: Rubin
HOP.NOTES: The Czechs classify this as a bittering hop, but with its Saaz background it is genetically similar to European aroma varieties. Bitterness is not as smooth as Saaz, and it lingers longer. Used for: Ales, Lagers Aroma: Similar to old middle European aroma hops. Substitutions: Saaz (CZ) Storage: Unknown 9-14% AA / 3-6% Beta

HOP.NAME: Saaz
HOP.NOTES: This traditional variety from the Czech Republic is grown on a limited basis in the U.S. A classic noble aroma that is famously used in Pilsners. Used for: Bohemian-style beers, Continental lagers, Wheats, Pilsener lagers, Ales, Pilsners Aroma: Seasoned herbal character Substitiutions: Czech Saaz, Polish Lublin, Sterling Storage: Poor 2-6% AA / 3-4.5% Beta

HOP.NAME: Santiam
HOP.NOTES: Triploid aroma selection derived from Tettnang and Hallertauer (1997) Used for: Lager, U.S. Pale Ale, Pilsner Substitutes: German Tettnang, Spalt, Spalt Select

HOP.NAME: Saphir
HOP.NOTES: A new noble breed as an alternative to Hallertau Mittelfrueh in an attempt to make it more disease resistant and commercially viable. Similar in character to Hallertau varieties. Used for: Pilsners, lagers, Belgian whites. Substitutes: Hallertau Mittelfrueh

HOP.NAME: Satus
HOP.NOTES: High alpha bittering hops from Yakima that is similar to Galena. Of recent origin. Substitutes: Galena

HOP.NAME: Select Spalt
HOP.NOTES: Bred from Hallertauer Mittelfrueh and Spalt in Germany. Spalt character. Used for: Lager, Pilsner, Noble aroma hop substitute Aroma: Very fine, spalt aroma Substitutes: Spalter, Saaz, Tettnang

HOP.NAME: Simcoe
HOP.NOTES: High alpha bittering hops with good aroma characteristics. Used for: IPAs Aroma: Citrus and pine-like aroma Substitutes: N/A

HOP.NAME: Sladek
HOP.NOTES: Hybrid variety of Saaz origin with noble hoppy taste and aroma. Generally recommended for middle-hopping about 20 min before end of boil. Not a replacement for Saaz, but complimentary in Lagers. Used for: Lager Substitutes: Saaz

HOP.NAME: Smaragd (Emerald)
HOP.NOTES: Perviously known as Emerald. A fine aroma variety with high bittering value. Used for: Alt, Kolsch, or blond ale. Aroma: Fine aroma, floral, fruity, spicy Substitutions: Unknown Storage: Fair 4-6% AA / 3.5-5.5% Beta

HOP.NAME: Sorachi Ace
HOP.NOTES: Developed by Sapporo Breweries and used in their beers - has a Brewer's gold and Saaz heritage. Works well with Citra and Simcoe. Used for: Saison, IPA, Pale Ale, Wheat, or other beer where lemon/citrus is desirable. Aroma: Striking lemon charachter, a bold hop for bold beers. Substitutes: Admiral, Cascade Storage: Unknown 10-16% AA / 6-7% Beta

HOP.NAME: Southern Cross
HOP.NOTES: Dual purpose with "European" flavor - from DSIR in 1994 Used for: European flavor bittering/aroma Aroma: Spicy, lemony, slight pine and wood flavors Substitutes: N/A

HOP.NAME: Sovereign
HOP.NOTES: English dwarf hop, a daughter of Whitbread Golding. Used for: ESB, other English Ales Aroma: Can be intensely fruity; also produces softer flavors, including stone fruits such as peach. Substitutes: Unknown Storage: Unknown 4.5-6.5% AA / 2.1-3.1% Beta

HOP.NAME: Spalt Spalter
HOP.NOTES: Available only from the Spalt region. fire aroma is unique despite genetic sililarities to Saaz, Tettnanger. Used for: Traditional German beers, Altbiers, Lagers Aroma: Fine/spicy, delicate, herbal, woody, floral Substitutes: Saaz, Tettnanger Storage: Poor 2.5-3.5 AA / 3-5% Beta

HOP.NAME: Spalter
HOP.NOTES: Used for: Traditional German bittering and aroma hops, Altbiers, Lagers Aroma: Mild, pleasant, slight spice Substitutes: Saaz, Tettnang Examples: Dusseldorf Altbiers

HOP.NAME: Spalter Select
HOP.NOTES: Bred from Hallertauer Mittelfrueh and Spalt in Germany. Solid replacement for Sazzer-type hops. Used for: Lager, Pilsner Aroma: Spicy, floral, and woody. Substitutes: Spalt Spalter, Saaz, Tettnanger Storage: Good/Fair 3-6.5% AA / 2.5-5% Beta

HOP.NAME: Sterling
HOP.NOTES: Flavor is a cross between Saaz and Mt Hood Used for: Lagers, Ales, Pilsners Aroma: Herbal, spicy, some floral and citrus hints Substitutes: Saaz, Polish Lublin

HOP.NAME: Sticklebract
HOP.NOTES: High alpha hops from DSIR research first released in 1972. Some of the same qualities as Northern Brewer Used for: Dual purpose Aroma: Pine-like with a hint of citrus Substitutes: Northern Brewer

HOP.NAME: Strisslespalt
HOP.NOTES: Aroma hops used widely in the Alsace area of France. Used for: Pilsner, lager, wheat Aroma: Medium intensity, pleasant, hoppy Substitutes: Mt Hood, Crystal, Hallertauer Hersbruck

HOP.NAME: Styrian Aurora (Super Styrian)
HOP.NOTES: Typical alpha: 7.0-9.0%. Moderate-alpha with powerful hoppy aroma, very versatile - try in US, Belgian, or English ales. Uses: All Ales, some lagers Aroma: Spicy, yet pleasant hoppiness Substitutes: Styrian Golding, Styrian Bobek Storage: Excellent 6.5-9.5% AA / 2.7-5.5% Beta

HOP.NAME: Styrian Bobek
HOP.NOTES: Derived from a Northern Brewer and Yugoslavian male TG. Low to moderate alpha and earthy, slightly fruity aroma. Uses: English Style Ales, ESB, Lager, Pilsner & Belgian-style Ales Aroma: Intense and pleasant hoppy aroma Substitutions: Styrian Golding, UK or US Fuggle, Willamette Storage: Good 3.5-7% AA / 4-6.1% Beta

HOP.NAME: Styrian Celeja
HOP.NOTES: Hybrid cross between Styrian Golding, Styrian Aurora, and Slovenian wild hops. Aroma is orange marmalade like Styrian Golding, but with a noble component. Used for: UK and Belgian ales or lagers. Aroma: Floral, fruit Substitutions: Unknown (Styrian Golding?) Storage: Unknown 3-6% AA / ??% Beta

HOP.NAME: Styrian Golding (Savinja Golding)
HOP.NOTES: A seedless version of Fuggle grown in Slovenia. Popular in Europe and the United Kingdom. Used for: All Ales and Lagers Aroma: Delicate, slightly spicy, soft, and floral aroma. Similar to Fuggle. Substitutes: Fuggle, Williamette, EKG Storage: Very Good 4.5-6% AA / 2-3.5% Beta

HOP.NAME: Styrian Goldings
HOP.NOTES: A seedless version of Fuggles grown in Slovenia Used for: Bittering, finishing for a wide variety of European Beers. Popular in Europe and the United Kingdom Aroma: Mild, soft, grassy, floral aroma. Similar to Fuggles. Substitutes: Fuggles, Williamette

HOP.NAME: Summer (Summer Saaz)
HOP.NOTES: Apricot and melon characters are more apparent when dry hopping. Used for: Ales Aroma: Subtle, light apricot and melon flavors Substitiutions: Unknown Storage: Unknown 4-7.5% AA / 4.8-6.7% Beta

HOP.NAME: Summit
HOP.NOTES: High alpha variety bred by American Dwarf Hop Assoc. Can be grown commercially on a low trellis. Aroma: Strong citrus, grapefruit notes. Substitutes: Warrior, Millenium, Columbus, Tomahawk, Zeus

HOP.NAME: Sun
HOP.NOTES: A very high alpha bittering hops from Yakima Valley, Washington Used for: Bittering (intense) Aroma: Pleasant, hoppy Substitutes: Other very high alpha US hops

HOP.NAME: Super Alpha
HOP.NOTES: High alpha hops released in 1976 by DSIR. European in character - clean crisp flavor and resin aroma. Used for: European Styles, General purpose bittering Aroma: Pleasant, resin like aroma Substitutes: N/A

HOP.NAME: Super Galena
HOP.NOTES: Super high alpha hops from Hopsteiner breeding program released in 2006. High alpha and beta content - comparable to Galena in bitterness and aroma profile. Used for: Primarily for bitterness. Substitutes: Galena

HOP.NAME: Super Pride
HOP.NOTES: A high alpha variation of the Pride of Ringwood hop variety. Features mild aromas, higher alpha content and low cohumulone levels. Used for: Primarily for bittering. Substitutes: Pride of Ringwood

HOP.NAME: Sylva
HOP.NOTES: Formerly Southern Saaz. Displays what's considered the traditional hoppy (with cedarwood notes) and spicy character of Saaz. Mostly an option for Southern Hemisphere brewers but an interesting variation on Saaz. Used for: Lagers Aroma: Complex and subtle, floral and herbal characteristics Substitutions: Hallertau Mittlefrüh, AU Helga Storage: Unknown 4-7.3% AA / 3-5% Beta

HOP.NAME: Target
HOP.NOTES: Used for: English ales and lagers Aroma: Robust aroma and flavor Substitutes: East Kent Goldings

HOP.NAME: Tettnang
HOP.NOTES: Used for: German ales, lagers and wheat beer Aroma: Noble, mild, fine, slightly spicy Substitutes: Saaz, Spalt Examples: Sam Adams Octoberfest, Anderson Valley ESB

HOP.NAME: Tettnang (Tettnang Tettnager)
HOP.NOTES: One of the four noble hops along with Saaz, Spalt, and Hallertau Mittelfrueh, a group of mainland European hops that are prized for their similar, delicate flavor and aroma profile. Used for: German ales, lagers, wheat Aroma: Noble, Mild and pleasant with balanced earthy, herbal and floral aroma impressions Substitutes: Saaz, Spalt, Hallertau Mittelfrueh Storage: Poor 2.5-6% AA / 3-5% Beta

HOP.NAME: Tillicum
HOP.NOTES: High alpha and high beta hops developed though Haas breeding program and released in 1995. Daughter variety of Galena and related to Chelan - so similar to both. Substitutes: Galena, Chelan

HOP.NAME: Tomahawk
HOP.NOTES: Part of the Columbus/Tomahak/Zeus (CTZ) group of super high alpha hops. Together these make up 1/4 of US hop acreage. Used for: High alpha hops used primarily for commercial bittering. Substitutes: Tomahawk, Zeus, Nugget, Galena, Chinook

HOP.NAME: Topaz
HOP.NOTES: Very high alpha hop variety from Australia. Used for commercial production primarily for its high alpha acid content and high bitterness.

HOP.NAME: Tradition
HOP.NOTES: Close descendant of Hallertauer Mittelfrueh bred for high yield. Used for: Lager, Pilsner, Bock, some Weizens Aroma: Fine - similar to Hallertauer Mittelfrueh Substitutes: Hallertauer Mittelfrueh, Liberty, Ultra

HOP.NAME: Tsingtao Flower
HOP.NOTES: Accounts for about 65% of acreage in China, the Chinese version of American Cluster. Used for: Unknown (Lager?) Aroma: Floral and Spicy Substitutions: Unknown Storage: Good 6-8% AA / 3-4.2% Beta

HOP.NAME: Ultra
HOP.NOTES: Triploid seedling of the German Hallertauer Variety Used for: Lager, Pilsner, wheat, finishing hops in ales Aroma: Good to outstanding - some Saaz like qualities Substitutes: Liberty, Hallertauer, Tradition, Saaz

HOP.NAME: Vanguard
HOP.NOTES: Diploid seedling made in 1982, released in 1997. Hallertau Mitterfrueh parentage. Used for: European lagers, ales Aroma: Strong aromatic notes Substitutes: Hallertauer Mittelfrueh

HOP.NAME: Vic Secret
HOP.NOTES: The clean, distinct fruit and pine characters of Vic Secret are best accessed by dry hopping or whirlpool additions. Late kettle additions have been found to impart a pleasant earthy character, but little fruit. Maintains very high levels of alpha acid so brewers may find it easier to craft the right balance in their beer by dry hopping. First commercial harvest in 2013. Uses: Ales, Lagers, Experimental Ales Aroma: Clean, distinct fruit and pine Substitutions: Unknown Storage: Unknown 14-17% AA / 2.2-2.8% Beta

HOP.NAME: Victoria
HOP.NOTES: Hi alpha hops grown in Victoria, Australia. It was created in 1976 and entered commercial production in the 1990s. Used for: Primarily for bittering due to high alpha content.

HOP.NAME: Wakatu (Hallertau Aroma)
HOP.NOTES: Formerly called Hallertau Aroma. Similar to German Hallertau but higher alpha. Excellent Dual Purpose hop, rounded floral aroma with hints of lime. Used for: Lager, Pils, Bock, Wheat, Kolsch, Helles, Belgian Ales. Aroma: Restrained floral notes and freshly zested lime Substitutions: US Hallertau, Liberty Storage: Good 6.5-8.5% AA / 8-9% Beta

HOP.NAME: Warrior
HOP.NOTES: High alpha hops from Yakima Chief Ranches. Also called YCR-5. Mild aroma and low cohumulone content - primarily for bittering. Used for: Ales, stouts Aroma: Neutral, clean, mild Substitutes: Nugget, Columbus, Magnum

HOP.NAME: Whitbread Golding Variety (WGV)
HOP.NOTES: Derived in England in 1911 from Bates Brewer. Some Golding characteristics, but lacking the full Goldings aroma. Used for: Ales Aroma: Pleasant, hoppy, slightly intense Substitutes: East Kent Goldings, Progress

HOP.NAME: Willamette
HOP.NOTES: Used for: Finishing American and British Ales Aroma: Mild, grassy, floral, slightly spicy Substitutes: Fuggles, East Kent Goldings Examples: Sierra Nevada Porter, Ballard Bitter

HOP.NAME: Zeus
HOP.NOTES: Super high alpha bittering hops developed in the Yakima Valley, WA Used for: Bittering, intense aroma Aroma: Aromatic, pleasant Substitutes: Other high alpha hops

HOP.NAME: Zythos
HOP.NOTES: A proprietary pellet blend. Designed to complement existing IPA and Pale Ale hop varieties. Used for: American-style Ale Aroma: Distinct tropical (pineapple) and citrus tones, with slight pine characteristics Substitutions: Unknown Storage: Unknown 10-12.5% AA / 4.7-6.2% Beta
